awd_titl_txt: Translation Regulation of Gene Expression in Toxic Dinoflagellates
awd_abstract_narration:
A number of dinoflagellate species are known to produce potent neurotoxins. Their blooms are commonly referred to as "red tides". An understanding of the genetic regulatory mechanisms that affect bloom growth and in particular the development of biomarkers to assess bloom growth status are essential for the development of scientifically sound management and mitigation policies. The genetic organization and regulation of these organisms has been shown to be distinct from nonprotist eukaryotes. Dinoflagellates are remarkable for their extremely large genomes that show little transcriptional regulation and with genes present as multiple tandem copies that are polycistronically processed through coupled trans-splicing and polyadenylation. A broad range of investigations has implicated mRNA recruitment as a major site of regulation of gene expression. However, relatively little is understood regarding translational initiation and its regulation in these organisms. 

In this project, a research team centered at the University of Maryland Institute of Marine and Environmental Technology will attempt to unravel the roles of the likely key players in translational regulation, eIF2 and eIF4, along with the spliced leader cap structures in regulating gene expression. Using the icthyotoxic dinoflagellate, Karlodinium veneficum and the toxin producing Karenia brevis, they will (1) determine whether changes in eIF2á phosphorylation underlie diel changes in gene expression or responses to different stressors; (2) begin characterization of the eIF2á-kinases from K. veneficum; (3) characterize the ability of K.veneficum eIF4E family member to bind to cap structures and translational binding partners; and (4) assess the role of K.veneficum eIF4E members in mRNA recruitment. Given the central role of translation in dinoflagellate gene expression, this should provide significant insight into mechanisms relevant to dinoflagellate growth, toxicity, and the regulation of harmful algal blooms. 

These results are expected to define a new paradigm for translational regulation in dinoflagellates, thus offering an innovative approach to bridge the gap between genomics and physiological complexity in dinoflagellates. Understanding the mechanism of translational regulation of dinoflagellate gene expression may begin to provide insight into the regulation of toxin production by these organisms and may be of direct use in monitoring/managing harmful algal blooms. 

Broader Impacts: The studies will provide critical insight into mechanisms relevant to dinoflagellate growth, toxicity, and the regulation of harmful algal blooms, with a long term goal of providing avenues for intervention.  The project will provide research experiences/training to high school students, undergraduate interns and area high school teachers. 

JOINT FUNDING BY NSF AND NIEHS:  The original proposal on which this project is based (R01 ES021949-01) was submitted to the National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences (NIH/NIEHS) in response to Funding Opportunity Announcement RFA-ES-11-013 , "Oceans, Great Lakes and Human Health (R01)", an opportunity jointly sponsored by NSF.   This project is cooperatively funded through separate awards from NSF and NIEHS.

por.por_cntn:
Translational control in dinoﬂagellates is now understood to be a crucial element in regulating gene expression. This is based on extensive studies of circadian bioluminescence and by more recent microarray, transcriptome and proteome analyses. However, before the work stemming from this award, almost nothing was known about the translational machinery or its regulation in dinoflagellates. This study has focused on translation initiation as a point of control of gene expression in dinoflagellates and in particular on the eukaryotic cap binding translation initiation factor eIF4E. Dr. Bachvaroff has assembled high quality dinoflagellate transcriptome datasets from Illumina RNAseq, across the dinoflagellate lineage. The resulting datasets have been a valuable resource for determining gene family diversity and relative transcript abundance across a suite of different dinoflagellate species. With this enlarged resource, we have greatly expanded our knowledge of the dinoflagellate translation machinery. In addition, we have used these datasets for exploring potential toxin synthesis pathways and the genes for acetyl-CoA carboxylase synthases, phosphopantetheinyl transferasesand the polyketide synthase/polyketide reductase/non-ribosomal peptide synthases. In addition to mining for translation factors and the genes for toxin synthesis pathways, we have used the dinoflagellate databases for investigating the role of codon bias as a potential player in translational regulation and have been able to resolve the internal phylogenetic relationships of the lineage. Using the well-assembled A. carteraedatabase, we have also assembled a virtual proteome for this species, useful for proteomic sequencing (unpublished). Along with this we have developed and implemented data analysis pipelines to process mass-spectometric-based 'omics data to confirm protein sequences, post-translational modifications, and interacting partners with high confidence.

For the first time, we have a resource for performing comprehensive genetic analysis of multiple dinoflagellate species that has allowed us to identify the core translational machinery of dinoflagellates with the anticipation that this will lead to a better understanding of their propensity to control gene expression post-transcriptionally. We have shown that these protists encode most of the known translational initiation factors thought to be essential for eukaryotic translational initiation with some notable exceptions. We have also shown that protein levels do not correspond to mRNA levels, reaffirming the importance of translational control. We have shown that dinoflagellates have a unique set of eIF4E family members. We have identified the 5'-cap structure and shown both diversity of sequence and nucleotide modifications of the spliced leader sequence. Such diversity in the SL, combined with multiple eIF4Es shows the high potential for regulation of mRNA recruitment in these organisms. Dinoflagellates also show unexpected variability in eIF2 and show little dependence on eIF2alpha phosphorylation in response to stress. 

We have also uncovered the fact that bacterized cultures of A. carteraemasks responses at the level of translation. Dinoflagellates are universally associated with bacteria in the ocean and the perceived wisdom in the dinoflagellate field is that the bacteria are probiotic and either improve, or are essential for, healthy growth. However, we have shown that A. carteraegrow well and to higher densities than bacterized cultures. Use of axenic cultures has covered dramatic changes in protein synthesis in response to temperature, nutrients and across the diel cycle. Intriguingly, the changes in protein synthetic rate across the diel cycle are accompanied by changes in the phosphorylation state of eIF4E-1a.
